user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName(osal_id_t *timer_id, const char *timebase_name)
{
    int32          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t objtype;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(timebase_name);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, timebase_name, timer_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t object_id, osal_index_t *ArrayIndex)
{
    uint32         max_id;
    uint32         obj_index;
    osal_objtype_t actual_type;
    int32          return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(ArrayIndex);

    obj_index   = OS_ObjectIdToSerialNumber_Impl(object_id);
    actual_type = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);

    /*
     * If requested by the caller, enforce that the ID is of the correct type.
     * If the caller passed OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED, then anything is allowed.
     */
    if (idtype != OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && actual_type != idtype)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }
    else
    {
        max_id = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(actual_type);
        if (max_id == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            *ArrayIndex = OSAL_INDEX_C(obj_index % max_id);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
explanation:
The fragments selected are all places where a const char * (timebase_name / name) is received or passed into internal checks/search routines (macros ARGCHECK/LENGTHCHECK, OS_Check_APINAME, and the object-name search path). These are the locations where string handling functions (e.g. strlen/strncpy/strcmp/memcpy/etc.) are likely to be invoked and therefore could lead to out-of-bounds accesses if the input is not a valid NUL-terminated buffer or if the length checks are faulty.

Other code fragments in the provided snippets do not need investigation for Rule 21.17 because they do not operate on character buffers or pass pointers to string functions: examples include OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex (operates on numeric IDs and indices), OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl (bitwise/id extraction), OS_TaskGetId_Impl (thread-specific id retrieval), OS_ObjectIdRelease and related token/transaction functions (object/token management), and other ID integer conversions. These integer/ID-only operations cannot cause accesses by string.h functions and therefore are outside the scope of Rule 21.17 in the shown code.
